To introduce it's new interactive music program, the Clovis Municipal Schools Music Department performed this piece for the Clovis community.

The community of Clovis, NM has a rich history of, and close connection to music. To celebrate our musical roots and strengthen connections during COVID-19 stay-at-home health orders, our award winning Music Department has worked with our school music teachers on an interactive program to share music with our families and community.

Keep checking back, our Music Department is working on more activities to do with your family, that will be posted as they become available.

We hope you enjoy the activities our talented staff have prepared for you!

ENGAGE NEW MEXICO: FREE ASSISTANCE, ACADEMIC COACHES FOR STUDENTS!
What is ENGAGE New Mexico?
For many students, going from a traditional classroom to learning from home can be a real challenge. New Mexico‚Äôs Public Education Department has partnered with Graduation Alliance to provide an extra layer of support for students and families who might be struggling with these changes.

Students who choose to participate in the program will get an academic coach to work with them to answer questions, connect them with resources, and develop a plan to get on track and finish the school year strong.

How does it work?
Graduation Alliance is reaching out to students through phone calls, emails, text messages and more to get students started.

What does it cost?
There is no cost for the student. ENGAGE New Mexico is completely free to students.

How do I join?
Call 505-340-3250 or email EngageNM@GraduationAlliance.com to get started.

SANDIA ELEMENTARY GRAB & GO MEAL DISTRIBUTION TO RESUME MONDAY, MAY 4
Grab & Go Meal distribution for school-aged children will resume at Sandia Elementary School on Monday, May 4, 2020. Breakfast and lunch meals will be distributed from 8:00 AM - 11:00 AM through contactless pick up.

With a daily service rate of approximately 100 students, and with the next closest meal site approximately a mile away, the District has determined that service provided by Sandia Elementary is critical. For that reason, additional measures have been taken to prepare and re-open the site to ensure meals are available to students in the surrounding community.

Earlier this week, the District announced it would cease meal distribution at the site for the remainder of the school year due to a potential risk of exposure of COVID-19.

Following the site closure, the District enacted COVID-19 exposure protocols and the facility was thoroughly disinfected. The decision to resume meal service at Sandia was made only after all potential exposure concerns were addressed.

CLOVIS MUNICIPAL SCHOOLS TO PROVIDE GRAB & GO MEALS DURING SPRING BREAK
During the week of Spring Break, March 23-27, Clovis Municipal Schools will offer free, Grab & Go meals to individuals 18 and under. Meals will be distributed from six schools in the district.

From 8-11 a.m. Monday, March 23, to Friday, March 27, Cameo, Highland, Lockwood and Sandia elementary schools and Marshall and Yucca middle schools will serve as distribution centers for food pick-up.

Meals will be distributed at the rear entrance of each cafeteria. Buildings are being kept secured during meal distribution. If the cafeteria door is closed, a doorbell is available. Children do not have to be a student of the district to receive a free meal.

An updated menu is available at www.clovis-schools.org

This modification to meal distribution is being made for the week of Spring Break only. Beginning Monday, March 30, distribution from all schools, with the exception of iAcademy at Lincoln Jackson and Los Ninos, will resume through the remainder of the school closure period.

PARTICIPANTS WANTED FOR THE NEW MEXICO COMMUNITY SURVEY
The Curry County Office of Substance Abuse Prevention is collecting data about alcohol, prescription painkillers (opioids), and other drugs.

They are asking community members to take 5 - 7 minutes to complete the New Mexico Community Survey (NMCS). This is completely anonymous.

The purpose of NMCS is to measure prevention efforts among our programs and to find where the gaps and barriers may occur. NMCS can also be used to strengthen our programs such as DWI, Teen Court, Foster Grandparents, etc. and help with application for new grants and bring in more funding.

There is also a chance to win $100 or $500 gift cards.

The survey can be taken at: https//tinyurl.com/nmcs2020

BARRY ROADRUNNERS GET STEM HELP FROM FIREFIGHTERS FOR EGG DROP!
Barry Elementary School 4th and 5th grade students got help from the Clovis Fire Department testing their egg drop designs. Firefighters dropped their eggs and parachute creations from the top of a ladder truck while students watched from below to see which eggs would make it through the fall intact.

This year, instead of doing a traditional science fair, 4th and 5th grade have participated in creating STEM projects as a group.

Instead of students completing a traditional science experiment at home and doing a science board, Barry developed a list of STEM projects that students could choose from that more closely aligned with NextGen science standards. Students were responsible for researching using their Chromebooks and completing trials to determine the best solution or approach to their STEM project. All projects were completed at school.

These projects will be displayed at the Barry STEMposium on Thursday from 1:15-2:45 in the gym.

GREAT JOB ROADRUNNERS!

HEATHER WOODARD SELECTED AS DIRECTOR OF STUDENT SUPPORT SERVICES
Heather Woodard has accepted the position of Director of Student Support Services. Prior to coming to Clovis, Ms. Woodard worked in Colorado Springs, Colorado, as a Youth Treatment Counselor, Communication Skills Disorders (CSD) Paraprofessional, and an Affective Needs Special Education Teacher.

In 2012, she joined Clovis Municipal Schools as a Special Education Liaison and continues serving children in that position.

Ms. Woodard received her Bachelor of Arts in Psychology and a Bachelor of Criminal Justice in 2006, and a Masters of Criminal Justice in 2008 from New Mexico State University.

In 2012, Ms. Woodard enrolled in the Alternative Teaching License Program at Pikes Peak BOCES in Colorado Springs and obtained her Special Education Generalist and Elementary Education license. She received her Master in Education Administration from Eastern New Mexico University in 2019.

This vacancy was created by the retirement of Becky Johnson. Ms. Woodard will begin her new position July 1, 2020.

CMS NEWS: DEBORAH WESTBROOK SELECTED AS DEPUTY DIRECTOR OF CHILD NUTRITION & WELL BEING
Deborah Westbrook has accepted the position of Deputy Director of Child Nutrition & Well Being.

Ms. Westbrook began her career with Clovis Municipal Schools in 2006 as a teacher. From 2006 to 2010, Ms. Westbrook taught 1st and 2nd grade with the District.

In August 2010, she became an Instructional Coach for Clovis Municipal Schools serving Parkview Elementary and the Arts Academy at Bella Vista. Ms. Westbrook was hired as the Principal of Lockwood Elementary School in 2012 and currently serves in that position.

Ms. Westbrook received her Bachelor of Science in Education in 2006 and a Master of Education in 2007 from Wayland Baptist University.

This vacancy was created by the retirement of Paul Klein.
